dt: {bc}a system of transmitting and reproducing graphic matter (such as printing or still pictures) by means of signals sent over telephone lines

pt: {sc}reproduction{/sc} {sc}duplicate{/sc} {sc}copy{/sc} {sc}facsimile{/sc} {sc}replica{/sc} mean a thing made to closely resemble another. {sc}reproduction{/sc} implies an exact or close imitation of an existing thing.
{sc}duplicate{/sc} implies a double or counterpart exactly corresponding to another thing.
{sc}copy{/sc} applies especially to one of a number of things reproduced mechanically.
{sc}facsimile{/sc} suggests a close reproduction often of graphic matter that may differ in scale.
{sc}replica{/sc} implies the exact reproduction of a particular item in all details
but not always in the same scale.

et: from the Latin phrase {it}fac simile{/it} "make alike," from {it}fac,{/it} singular imperative of {it}facere{/it} "to make, do, perform" + {it}simile,{/it} neuter of {it}similis{/it} "like, similar" {ma}{mat|fact|}, {mat|same:1|}{/ma}

The phrase {it}fac simile{/it} was well-known from its occurrence in one of the {it}Distichs of Cato,{/it} a collection of proverbial wisdom (3rd-4th centuries {sc}a.d.{/sc}) commonly used as a Latin textbook from the Middle Ages into the 18th century (though its meaning in the distich is different): "Qui simulat verbis, nec corde est fidus amicus, tu quoque fac simile—sic ars deluditur arte." ("If someone makes a pretense in speech and is not a true friend, you do likewise as well—and so art will be duped by art.")
shortdef: a system of transmitting and reproducing graphic matter (such as printing or still pictures) by means of signals sent over telephone lines

dt: {bc}a copy that is not exact but is fairly close

dt.t: The house is a {it}reasonable facsimile{/it} of his original home.

dt: sometimes used in a joking way

dt.t: I can speak French, or at least a {it}reasonable facsimile{/it} of French.
